Module nl.naturalis.common
Package nl.naturalis.common

Class ObjectMethods

  • java.lang.Object
    • nl.naturalis.common.ObjectMethods
  • public class ObjectMethods
extends Object
    General methods applicable to objects of any type.
    Author:
    Ayco Holleman

    • Method Detail

      • isEmpty

        public static boolean isEmpty​(Object obj)

        Returns whether or not the provided object is empty. Returns true if the argument is:

        • null
        • an empty String
        • an empty Collection
        • an empty Map
        • a zero-length array
        • a zero-size Sizeable
        • an empty Emptyable

        Otherwise this method returns false.

        Parameters:
        obj - The object to be tested
        Returns:
        Whether or not it is empty

      • notEmpty

        public static boolean notEmpty​(Object obj)
        Returns the inverse of isEmpty.
        Parameters:
        obj - The object to be tested
        Returns:
        Whether or not it is non-empty

      • deepNotEmpty

        public static boolean deepNotEmpty​(Object obj)

        Returns whether or not the argument is recursively non-empty. More specifically, this method returns true if:

        • obj is a non-empty (non-primitive) array with only deepNotEmpty elements
        • obj is a non-empty Collection with only deepNotEmpty elements
        • obj is a non-empty Map, with only deepNotEmpty values (NB map keys are not checked for empty-ness)
        • obj is a non-empty object of any other type

        Otherwise this method returns false.

        Parameters:
        obj - The object to be tested
        Returns:
        Whether or not it is recursively non-empty

      • deepNotNull

        public static boolean deepNotNull​(Object obj)

        Returns whether or not the argument is recursively non-null. More specifically, this method returns true if:

        • obj is not null
        • obj is an empty array or a non-empty array with only non-null elements
        • obj is an empty Collection or a non-empty Collection with only non-null elements
        • obj is an empty Map non-empty Map with only non-null values (NB Map keys are not checked for empty-ness.)

        Otherwise this method returns false. Contrary to deepNotEmpty, this method returns true for empty arrays, collections and maps. It only checks that the values they do contain are non-null.

        Parameters:
        obj - The object to be tested
        Returns:
        Whether or not it is recursively non-null

      • emptyToNull

        public static <T> T emptyToNull​(T obj)
        Returns null if the argument is empty, else the argument itself.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of the argument
        Parameters:
        obj - The argument
        Returns:
        The argument itself or null

      • e2nEquals

        public static boolean e2nEquals​(Object obj1,
                                Object obj2)

        Tests the provided arguments for equality using empty-equals-null semantics. This is more or less equivalent to: 

         Objects.equals(emptyToNull(obj1), emptyToNull(obj2))
        More specifically:

        1. null equals an empty String
        2. null equals an empty Collection
        3. null equals an empty Map
        4. null equals a zero-length array
        5. null equals an empty Emptyable
        6. null equals a zero-size Sizeable
        7. For any other pair of arguments this method returns the result of Objects.equals(obj1, obj2)
        8. An empty instance of one type (e.g. String) is not equal to an empty instance of another type (e.g. Set)
        Parameters:
        obj1 - The 1st of the pair of objects to compare
        obj2 - The 2nd of the pair of objects to compare
        Returns:

      • e2nDeepEquals

        public static boolean e2nDeepEquals​(Object obj1,
                                    Object obj2)
        Recursively tests the arguments for equality using empty-equals-null semantics. In other words, for arrays, collections and maps, elements c.q. values are also compared using e2nDeepEquals.
        Parameters:
        obj1 - The 1st of the pair of objects to compare
        obj2 - The 2nd of the pair of objects to compare
        Returns:

      • e2nHashCode

        public static int e2nHashCode​(Object obj)
        Generates a hash code for the provided object using using empty-equals-null semantics. That is: null and empty objects all have hash code zero. Therefore maps and sets relying on empty-equals-null semantics to find keys and elements will likely have to fall back more often on e2nEquals or e2nDeepEquals.
        Parameters:
        obj - The object to generate a hash code for
        Returns:

      • e2nHash

        public static int e2nHash​(Object... objs)
        Generates a hash code for the provided arguments using using empty-equals-null semantics. See Object.hashCode().
        Parameters:
        objs - The objects to generate a hash code for
        Returns:

      • ifTrue

        public static <T> T ifTrue​(boolean condition,
                           T value,
                           UnaryOperator<T> then)
        Returns value if the condition evaluates to true, else the result of the specified operation on value. For example: 
         String s = ifTrue(ignoreCase, name, String::toLowerCase);
        Type Parameters:
        T - The input and return type
        Parameters:
        condition - The condition to evaluate
        value - The value value to return or to apply the transformation to
        then - The operation to apply if the condition evaluates to true
        Returns:

      • ifNotNull

        public static <T,​U> U ifNotNull​(T value,
                                      Function<T,​U> then)
        Returns the result of passing value to then if value is not null, else the value supplied by otherwise. For example: 
         String[] strs = ifNotNull("Hello World", s -> s.split(" "));
        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of the first argument
        U - The return type
        Parameters:
        value - The value to test
        then - The transformation to apply to the value if it is not null
        Returns:

      • ifNotNull

        public static <T,​U> U ifNotNull​(T value,
                                      Function<T,​U> then,
                                      Supplier<U> otherwise)
        Returns the result of passing value to then if value is not null, else the value supplied by otherwise. For example: 
         String[] strs = ifNotNull("Hello World", s -> s.split(" "), () -> new String[0]);
        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of the first argument
        U - The return type
        Parameters:
        value - The value to test
        then - The transformation to apply to the value if it is not null
        otherwise - A supplier providing the default value
        Returns:
